question: In the error-correcting code with \( k = 10 \), it is stated that all odd numbers of errors will be detected. If the probability of an error occurring in a single position is \( p \), what is the probability of an undetected error occurring?
solution:
In the error-correcting code with \( k = 10 \), only even numbers of errors can go undetected. The probability of an undetected error occurring can be calculated as follows:

The probability of an undetected error (which occurs with 2, 4, 6, 8, or 10 errors) is given by the sum of the probabilities of these events:

\[
P(\text{undetected error}) = P(2 \text{ errors}) + P(4 \text{ errors}) + P(6 \text{ errors}) + P(8 \text{ errors}) + P(10 \text{ errors})
\]

Using the binomial probability formula, we can express this as:

\[
P(k \text{ errors}) = C(n, k) p^k (1 - p)^{n-k}
\]

For \( n = 10 \):

\[
P(\text{undetected error}) = C(10, 2) p^2 (1 - p)^8 + C(10, 4) p^4 (1 - p)^6 + C(10, 6) p^6 (1 - p)^4 + C(10, 8) p^8 (1 - p)^2 + C(10, 10) p^{10}
\]

Calculating each term:

\[
= 45 p^2 (1 - p)^8 + 210 p^4 (1 - p)^6 + 210 p^6 (1 - p)^4 + 45 p^8 (1 - p)^2 + p^{10}
\]

Thus, the probability of an undetected error is 

\[
\boxed{45 p^2 (1 - p)^8 + 210 p^4 (1 - p)^6 + 210 p^6 (1 - p)^4 + 45 p^8 (1 - p)^2 + p^{10}}
\]
